natural problem: Our club has 25 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, and treasurer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office?
natural solution: The president can be any of the 25 members, the secretary can be any of the 24 remaining members, and the treasurer can be any of the remaining 23 members. There are $25\times 24\times 23=\boxed{13,\!800}$ ways.

a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 25 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, and treasurer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office? The final Answer is 13,\!800
 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 25 members, the secretary can be any of the 24 remaining members, and the treasurer can be any of the remaining 23 members. There are $25\times 24\times 23=\boxed{13,\!800}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
assumes h0 : "fact 25 = 15511210043330985984000000"
shows  "25 * 24 * 23 = 13800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If the factorial of 25 is 15511210043330985984000000, then what is the product of 25, 24, and 23? The final answer is 13800.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n p s t :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 25"
and h1 : "p = 1"
and h2 : "s = 1"
and h3 : "t = 1"
and h4 : "p + s + t \<le> n"
shows  "fact n div (fact (n - p - s - t)) = 13800"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 25 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, and treasurer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office? The final Answer is 13,\!800
 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 25 members, the secretary can be any of the 24 remaining members, and the treasurer can be any of the remaining 23 members. There are $25\times 24\times 23=\boxed{13,\!800}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
fixes n p s t :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 25"
and h1 : "p = 1"
and h2 : "s = 1"
and h3 : "t = 1"
and h4 : "p + s + t \<le> n"
shows  "fact n div (fact (n - p - s - t)) = 13800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given that $n=25$, $p=1$, $s=1$, and $t=1$, and that $p+s+t \leq n$, find the value of $\frac{n!}{(n-p-s-t)!}$ The final answer is $13800$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 25"
shows  "fact members div (fact (members - 3)) = 13800"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 25 members, and wishes to pick a president, secretary, and treasurer.  In how many ways can we choose the officers, if individual members can only hold at most one office? The final Answer is 13,\!800
 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 25 members, the secretary can be any of the 24 remaining members, and the treasurer can be any of the remaining 23 members. There are $25\times 24\times 23=\boxed{13,\!800}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
fixes members :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 25"
shows  "fact members div (fact (members - 3)) = 13800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a group of 25 members, how many ways can a committee of 3 members be selected? The final answer is 13800.

a_3.formal problem:

fixes members :: nat and officers :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 25"
and h1 : "officers = 3"
shows  "fact members div (fact (members - officers)) = 13800"
a_3.formal solution:

 ### Proof
 The president can be any of the 25 members, the secretary can be any of the 24 remaining members, and the treasurer can be any of the remaining 23 members. There are $25\times 24\times 23=\boxed{13,\!800}$ ways.
 *)

theorem
fixes members :: nat and officers :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 25"
and h1 : "officers = 3"
shows  "fact members div (fact (members - officers)) = 13800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a group of 25 members, how many ways can 3 officers be selected? The final answer is 13,800 ways.

fixes club_members :: nat
assumes h0 : "club_members = 25"
shows  "fact club_members / (fact (club_members - 3)) = 13800"
a_6.formal solution:

 The president can be any of the 25 members, the secretary can be any of the 24 remaining members, and the treasurer can be any of the remaining 23 members. There are $25\times 24\times 23=\boxed{13,\!800}$ ways.

theorem
fixes club_members :: nat

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
